PART 4
High-level Roadmap








Realizing that AI is necessary to solve today's societal challenges, and given the suggested Key principles, what action would be necessary to best and in the shortest possible time contribute to the Vision, i.e. an ecosystem with ambition and capabilities to substantially contribute to a great democratic society with a high quality of life, and societal and business solutions valuable to Sweden and other countries? 
Early 2024 the Swedish AI ecosystem is well prepared and Sweden stands a good chance to benefit from AI. The Swedish private sector is highly diverse, has a strong track record of being innovative, and includes several significant frontrunners. The interest in AI and the collaborative spirit in the public sector are quickly growing and good examples of valuable solutions are being deployed. The combination of WASP’s investment in fundamental research and talent, and AI Sweden's dedicated effort to driving adoption across sectors, is from what we can see a unique strength that few countries can match. 
This High-level Roadmap therefore focuses on the critical aspects that still are missing and that we believe would have a high impact. These center around national, i.e. government initiated, leadership, investments, and other efforts to scale the benefits of AI.








Phase 1 - Actions with high impact
Among the knowledgeable leaders in academia and the private and public sectors, we see a clear consensus that Sweden needs to act urgently to ensure its competitiveness and continuous ability to develop its welfare. A number of highly prioritized actions should be put in place immediately, below the most critical. Below are the most urgent, preferably acted upon during 2024.













In process





The National AI commission - Government

The Swedish government has announced an AI commission that is tasked to analyze and come up with concrete proposals on how AI can promote Sweden as a leading research nation, advanced industrial nation and ambitious welfare nation.
This is an excellent step that should lead to concrete deliverables that the government acts upon starting 2024 and further alignment among key stakeholders in the Swedish AI ecosystem. 
Press release 
Directive















Urgent





Government competence, leadership and direction - Government

The government should show clear direction and leadership. Given the highly decentralized Swedish public sector and the large number of leaders and decision-makers on various levels, government leadership and direction become even more important.  
Government leadership and direction should for instance include Clearly appointing a minister responsible for AI, preferably with horizontal responsibilities across ministries
Identify and communicate the potential in the private and public sector
Set a strategy toward realizing such potential 
Establish active international collaboration with leading nations and participation in relevant international initiatives and decision-making (not least in the European Union)
Clearly separate AI from the broadly used term digitalization
The Government should also actively increase competence and use of AI throughout the government office (“Regeringskansliet”). Ideally, each ministry would appoint two to three knowledgeable and responsible for AI-related questions, as well as having access to coordinating and strategic expertise available for government and government offices.



Dedicated investments on AI - Government

AI is likely the strongest driving force behind the mentioned transformation of society and key leaders in Sweden, such as business leaders, policy-makers, and leaders within the government should immediately start discussing AI according to its magnitude and investing to realize the identified potential. 
Dedicated investments are necessary to demonstrate leadership, substantially increase the knowledge level, build strategic resources build an active ecosystem, and scale collaboration across sectors. The investments should be ramped up towards an ambitious level related to the identified potential.
And, the potential is very high. According to DIGG, in the public sector alone and based on available technology by 2019 (i.e. long before generative AI) the estimated potential is SEK 140 billion per year, or more than SEK 10 billion in missed opportunity for every month that passes without action. 
Government investments will be matched by minimum corresponding investments in both the private and public sectors, and lead to ripple effects and clearly higher economic value throughout the ecosystem. One example is this report from Teknikföretagen. 
According to An AI Strategy for Sweden, government investments in AI should include funding programs that lead to a substantial increase in the knowledge level in the ecosystem, develop strategic resources that are shared with many, enable frontrunners to move faster and share generously, scales the building of the AI ecosystem and collaboration across sectors, and incentivizes international collaboration with leading nations and organizations.
We recommend that the overall investments in AI include significant investments through Vinnova, where the collaborative structures, ecosystems, and knowledge already are in place. 
For reference, one of the most natural countries for Sweden to collaborate with is Canada where between 2022 and 2023, $2.57 billion was invested in AI research in the country, as total AI investment reached $8.64 billion. See more here. 
Further on the top 10 Countries Leading in AI Research and technology in 2023, see here.



Increase investments in innovation in general - Government & Ministry of Climate and Enterprise

With the pace of technological development and demonstrated value and implications, we can conclude that we are in the early phase of significantly transformative times. Perhaps the most transformative times in history. In such times, government general investments driving innovation, applied research and change are more important than ever. 
General investments in innovation and applied research advance development in many sectors and as one effect of many, lead to better generation, higher maturity, and availability of data and data management.
Sweden should make sure it is on par with nations investing the most related to its GDP. 
Again we recommend building on existing structures, and within the total investments in innovation in general, include significantly increased investments through Vinnova.



Upskilling and reskilling - Ministry of Education and Research

Broad programs should be put in place to add AI skills to all educational fields and levels, as well as programs incentivizing both private and public sectors to invest in up- and reskilling of the existing workforce. This is especially important for non-STEM education. 
Introducing new courses in existing curriculums in Universities and University Colleges has proven to take a long time and the Ministry of Education and Research should act to both incentivize and force change, as well as establish new ways for the educational system to bring AI to their students.



Upskilling and reskilling - Universities and University Colleges

The transformation of society means that a large share of the existing workforce needs to be up or reskilled. Although there are existing structures and initiatives, we believe that much more must be done. 
According to the Swedish law “Högskolelagen” " universities and University Colleges have the responsibility for lifelong learning, and Universities and University Colleges should collaborate and challenge existing structures to offer educational opportunities in new ways that scales, such as outside of formal curriculums (we believe the students are interested), professional education basis. 
Good small-scale examples with unexpectedly high interest:    
AI for Executives - professional education offered by three universities in collaboration 
AI - Organization, value, and adoption - where hundreds of students learn about AI in an extracurricular activity




Dedicated investments on AI - Regions and Municipalities

Regions and Municipalities have two significant challenges related to AI
Accelerating their use of AI to manage how demographic changes will impact the available workforce
Making sure their regional private sectors adopt AI and maintain competitiveness.
Regions and Municipalities should invest in their competence and use of AI, and make sure they participate in national collaboration. 
Regions and Municipalities should also invest in programs and projects enabling their regional private sectors to adopt AI. AI Sweden is one such structure that enables regions and municipalities to gain from national and collective investments and participate in active ecosystems and collaboration across sectors.



Competence and use of AI - Government agencies and State owned companies

Unlike Regions and Municipalities, many Government agencies and State-owned companies lack "natural" urgency and incentives to reform through AI. Government agencies will be forced to change due to demographic challenges but for many state-owned companies, the government needs to create and communicate pressure for change to happen. Failure or inability to act will lead to erosion of relevance when citizens and taxpayers compare the outcome and services to other private and public organizations.
But regardless of government pressure or incentive, we recommend every government agency and state-owned company to proactively build AI competence, identify concrete use cases with both high potential and short development time, participate in national collaboration, and identify other organizations serving as good examples and inspiration.



Competence & leadership - Political parties

Political parties should ensure that their relevance, decision-making, and ability to contribute to the positive development of society is built on a solid understanding of AI, its potential, and implications. 
  
Specifically, party leaders and other leading party representatives should demonstrate a basic understanding and be able to engage in discussions about use cases, potentials, and risks.










Phase 2 - Scaling the efforts
One trend is very clear, the ones who understand AI the best, also invest the most. And they increase their efforts regularly. With the urgent actions above in place, decision-makers throughout society will rapidly be motivated to increase investments in scaling adoption and managing the benefits and challenges of AI. 
When this realization starts to happen broadly, we believe many more initiatives and changes will start to be relevant. These could include the following:
A broad update of the educational system, both in terms of a broad use of AI-based learning tools, and new curriculums adapted to the way AI transforms society. In other words, not teach AI skills, but more of, for instance, interpersonal skills and collective intelligence  
An Increasing need and urgency to up- and reskill the existing workforce 
Incentivizing collaboration and the use of certain types of solutions throughout regions, municipalities, and government agencies, through conditional government grants and investments.
Strongly improved regulations for international talent and workforce opportunities to choose and work in Sweden based on an international benchmark
Revision of regulations on the use of public data, public procurement, and other obstacles to using AI. 
Mandatory AI knowledge and skills among leaders and decision-makers in both the private and the public sector
Integrate AI-powered decision-making
We also believe investments will be necessary to compensate for the decentralized public sector and to address growing democratic issues related to welfare services not being provided at equal quality and cost by laggards compared to the best frontrunners. 
Further, AI will be a driving force for deepened international collaboration within the EU, the Nordic countries, and NATO. Over time we expect there to be strong applied research bodies within some of these partnerships to accelerate the development, and Sweden will at the mid-term horizon need to focus on deployment rather than domestic research.








Phase 3 - Manage an AI-driven future 
The future society will be different from today’s. AI will come with many implications that we struggle to foresee today and that will likely need to be managed with a completely different set of tools (such as regulation, taxation, and governance) than today. 
Nations that prepare early and intentionally establish cultures, foresight, and structures that enable adaptivity should have good chances to be the best at managing the economic, social, and other challenges the AI transformation might bring.



















PART 5
Responsible use of AI








AI has the potential to transform whole industries as well as society at large. It is of the highest importance that this is done in a safe, lawful, and responsible way to make sure people are not harmed directly or indirectly through applied AI solutions, while also unlocking the potential that AI brings.
The pace of AI development is extremely high. This brings a strong need for paying close attention to the implications of adopting AI while also building trust on a societal level and over time. Each AI use case has unique risks and considerations that require context-specific approaches. We also need to support experimentation and exploration as this is where potential risks are concretized and addressed. 
Moreover, due to the speed of development, we are not yet able to foresee all possible risks and opportunities with AI. It is therefore paramount that we build a strong AI ecosystem that is capable of applying responsible principles over time. A robust AI ecosystem requires national and international collaboration, active contribution and participation of stakeholders, and sharing of information and best practices.
The adoption of AI spans many fields, both technical such as data management and infrastructure, and non-technical areas such as behavioral sciences and people management. Given this, a multi-disciplinary approach throughout the lifecycle of AI development and application will increase our understanding of how AI solutions will be the most useful without producing undesirable results and the effect on society as a whole. 
For organizations developing or using AI, we encourage using existing work done by organizations such as EU, NATO, OECD, and UNESCO, and we would like to place additional emphasis on some specific perspectives.













Lawfulness and transparency: All AI solutions should be developed and used within the rule of the law and stakeholders should be held accountable accordingly. We strongly advocate for proportionate and reasonable transparency about how AI systems are developed and work. This involves communicating the capabilities and limitations of AI understandably to all stakeholders, including end users and citizens.
















Ethical and fair: AI systems must be designed and operated in a manner that respects human rights, values, and cultural diversity. This includes mitigating risks with AI algorithms such as bias and discrimination. It is essential to consider ethical implications at every stage of AI development and deployment.















Safety and robustness: AI systems must be reliable, controllable, and secure. They should function as intended under various conditions and be resilient to manipulations and errors. This includes safeguarding against malicious use of AI technologies and ensuring that AI does not pose unintended harm to people or the environment.












Assuming an agreement on the above principles, the challenge now lies in turning them into action and translating them into real-life scenarios and applications. Here, we have a responsibility to also use AI where appropriate and to address our time’s most pressing global challenges.

UNESCO: recommendation on the ethics of artificial intelligence

An AI Strategy for Sweden






 











AI is a necessity for solving key societal challenges, staying competitive, and in general preserving and developing a great democratic society with a high quality of life.
The objective of An AI Strategy for Sweden is therefore to develop Sweden’s capabilities to strongly benefit from the potential of AI and solve key societal and business challenges.











Sweden has a tremendous opportunity to solve key societal and business challenges with the use of AI. It requires bold leadership, scaled collaboration across sectors, and dedicated government investments.















 






Martin Svensson
Managing Director - AI Sweden










Like many other countries, Sweden faces growing grand challenges such as increasing energy demand, demographics, crime, and national security. The consequences of the demographics alone turn the usage of AI and modern technology into a necessity, as the welfare sector otherwise would need 100% of the newly graduated workforce at the same time as there are limits to tax raises. Today’s solutions are simply not the solutions that will build the future of society. 
In the private sector, many companies are seeing rapidly increasing international competition and signs of coming dramatic disruption, often driven by new possibilities enabled by AI. To preserve and strengthen its competitiveness, Sweden should make sure its private sector and not least, large exporting corporations increase their knowledge and investments in AI. 
Countries that early on have invested heavily in AI research and talent through research-focused strategies (e.g Canada) now face a crucial choice to invest beyond research and experimentation to enable adoption or lag behind. While others have to change their strategies, Sweden on the other hand has an opportunity to act fast and implement an adoption-focused strategy from the beginning. A bold strategy focused on generating value and adoption across industry and society would be a driver for collaboration, collective learning, and talent attraction. However, to succeed with such a strategy and compensate for the lack of early investments in AI, Sweden needs to collaborate with leading nations to access expertise and talent. 
Sweden should act now and substantially invest in developing capabilities throughout sectors, throughout society. This Strategy therefore focuses on AI being adopted and generating sustainable value in the private and public sector, as well as across fields of research. 
Further, the Strategy is inspired by the strategies of Canada, USA, UK, Germany, and Singapore. Several representatives for these countries have also been involved in the reference groups giving input and feedback. 
This Strategy has been developed by the management of AI Sweden, the national center for applied AI with the mission to Accelerate the use of AI for the benefit of our society, our competitiveness, and for everyone living in Sweden, with feedback and input from two reference groups (to be disclosed when work completed).

For Sweden especially, with the high decentralization of the Swedish public sector (e.g. 21 regions, 290 municipalities, 350+ government agencies), collaboration becomes even more important as very few organizations individually are capable of building and managing necessary infrastructure, data, and solutions. Significant activities and investments compensation for decentralization must be put in place on all levels from government and downwards.








Nästa
Föregående
















“The research community, industry, and Government play important, interconnected roles to enable the development and deployment of AI solutions. It is critical for Singapore to enhance partnerships across these stakeholders to strengthen our collective capabilities and drive our overall national AI effort.”
From: Singapore's AI Strategy
















“With new opportunities, risks, and threats to prosperity and security at stake, the promise and peril associated with this foundational technology are too vast for any single actor to manage alone. As a result, cooperation is inherently needed to equally mitigate international security risks, as well as to capitalize on the technology’s potential to transform enterprise functions, mission support, and operations.”
From: An Artificial Intelligence Strategy for NATO












More reading and background





Relevant strengths and weaknesses of Sweden

When developing an AI strategy, Sweden has some comparative advantages and disadvantages worth considering. 
Relative to its size, Sweden has both many diverse exporting enterprises as well as a rich startup community, which should mean that many companies are exposed to competitive markets and need to be early adopters.
Sweden also ranks high on innovation and potential benefits of AI, has internationally recognized quality management, and has a history of successfully managing change both within organizations and for society at large. The culture of early delegation with a lack of management involvement can on the other side lead to slow AI adoption and poor prioritization.
The public sector is well organized and holds exceptionally valuable data, but is also highly decentralized with many small organizations facing difficulties in establishing relevant leadership, attracting relevant competence and investing according to the opportunities. Several other sectors are also lagging for similar reasons, not least the vast number of SMEs:s.
The education system is divided between humanities and science. The transformation initiated by AI implies the need for more workers skilled in several fields. Sweden has few programs overlapping disciplines and there are few indications that this will change during the coming years.
Like many other EU nations, Sweden has focused on regulations rather than the combination of implementation and regulation. The latter is more common in North America and Asia which means these continents also learn about disadvantages and the need for relevant regulations.



Global ranking

According to the Global AI Index Sweden ranks as number 17 in total, and as follows in the seven categories:
Talent - 15 
Infrastructure - 21 
Operating Environment - 2
Research - 13
Development - 17
Government Strategy - 44
Commercial - 16  
What clearly stands out is the lack of Government Strategy.

















PART 3
Key principles - the core strategy & mindset








The Key Principles constitute the core of this strategy and should serve as a mindset that permeates, guides, and aligns actions, investments, and initiatives associated with this strategy. 
If all relevant actions or investments were based and mapped against these principles we believe Sweden would quickly see positive effects and over time maximize the long-term impact throughout the ecosystem. 
As an example, an AI commission at the government level should collaborate with the best international peers, be structured across ministries, attract some of the best talent for the assignment, and catalyze investments and actions according to all Key principles.













Engage and learn from the best nations and international organizations
Given the pace of development internationally and that many of the objectives are best managed on an international level, Sweden should actively seek partnerships with like-minded countries, companies, research institutes, non-profit organizations, think tanks, and individuals, especially where there is a ground for mutual learning and development. 
International collaboration should preferably be focused and result in a high density of interactions with selected ecosystems. 
In parallel, Sweden must make it easier for international talent to stay, study, work, live, and remain in Sweden, as well as incentivize and enable the private and public sectors to recruit talent internationally.  
















Substantially increase the knowledge level and competence everywhere in the ecosystem 
A higher level of knowledge leads to better insights and understanding of what investments, actions, and competence are needed, and as a key principle leaders throughout society should strive to increase the knowledge level and add competence (knowledgeable talent and workforce) in their respective organization, whether that is within government, private companies, public organizations, ministries, government agencies or academia. 
Further, all initiatives quickly increasing the overall competence in the ecosystem should be incentivized and prioritized. More competence is necessary at all levels of education and in all professional roles relevant to AI adoption (not least leaders, change makers, legal experts, AI practitioners, and domain experts). 

















Invest in strategic resources that can be shared with many 
Incentives and funding for the development of strategic and important resources for sovereignty, independence, and scaled adoption (such as national computational infrastructure, Swedish large language models, methods for how to build decentralized systems, AI adoption tools for leaders, etc) should be built in broad collaborations and made available as widely as possible. 
AI Sweden (among others) has demonstrated that the willingness among international and Swedish companies and organizations to jointly invest in knowledge and strategic resources enabling the adoption of AI is significant. When structured on a truly collaborative basis and with strong sharing mechanisms (such as My AI), the return on investment can be significant. 
















Enable the best to perform even better and incentivize them to share generously 
By identifying and recognizing forerunners, i.e. companies and organizations investing and demonstrating real value by AI, Sweden would quickly reinforce a pay-it-forward culture encouraging responsibility, change, investments, and collaboration. 
Ambitious forerunners also exist in both private and public sectors in Sweden. These companies and organizations should be enabled and incentivized to move even faster and generate more value given that they share generously with others in the ecosystem.

















Build an ecosystem and scale collaboration across sectors
To foster and drive collaboration, Sweden should scale initiatives that build the ecosystem and facilitate collaboration. This should include a strong ambition to compensate for the high decentralization of the public sector through investments in collaboration and sharing, both between several public organizations and between public and private organizations. 
Facilitation of collaboration should include incentives for consortiums to build joint advanced solutions, structures, and regulations enabling access to real-world data and in general build on mechanisms that allow fast pace and adaptivity. 
 
Sweden should also consider investing in one or two “moonshots”, e.g. large-scale initiatives where many actors come together to solve a grand challenge.













References

OECD overview of national AI strategies (from 2021)
USA National AI R&D Strategy
USA National Security Strategy on AI 
USA  NATIONAL ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT STRATEGIC PLAN, 2023 UPDATE 
Strengthening and Democratization the U.S. AI Innovation System
Pan-Canadian AI Strategy
UK National AI Strategy
Singapore National AI Strategy
Japan Revised AI Strategy
Norway National Strategy AI
Denmark National Strategy for AI
Australia Strategy for Generative AI
NATO AI Strategy
EU thoughts on AI Strategy





















PART 4
High-level Roadmap








Realizing that AI is necessary to solve today's societal challenges, and given the suggested Key principles, what action would be necessary to best and in the shortest possible time contribute to the Vision, i.e. an ecosystem with ambition and capabilities to substantially contribute to a great democratic society with a high quality of life, and societal and business solutions valuable to Sweden and other countries? 
Early 2024 the Swedish AI ecosystem is well prepared and Sweden stands a good chance to benefit from AI. The Swedish private sector is highly diverse, has a strong track record of being innovative, and includes several significant frontrunners. The interest in AI and the collaborative spirit in the public sector are quickly growing and good examples of valuable solutions are being deployed. The combination of WASP’s investment in fundamental research and talent, and AI Sweden's dedicated effort to driving adoption across sectors, is from what we can see a unique strength that few countries can match. 
This High-level Roadmap therefore focuses on the critical aspects that still are missing and that we believe would have a high impact. These center around national, i.e. government initiated, leadership, investments, and other efforts to scale the benefits of AI.








Phase 1 - Actions with high impact
Among the knowledgeable leaders in academia and the private and public sectors, we see a clear consensus that Sweden needs to act urgently to ensure its competitiveness and continuous ability to develop its welfare. A number of highly prioritized actions should be put in place immediately, below the most critical. Below are the most urgent, preferably acted upon during 2024.













In process





The National AI commission - Government

The Swedish government has announced an AI commission that is tasked to analyze and come up with concrete proposals on how AI can promote Sweden as a leading research nation, advanced industrial nation and ambitious welfare nation.
This is an excellent step that should lead to concrete deliverables that the government acts upon starting 2024 and further alignment among key stakeholders in the Swedish AI ecosystem. 
Press release 
Directive















Urgent





Government competence, leadership and direction - Government

The government should show clear direction and leadership. Given the highly decentralized Swedish public sector and the large number of leaders and decision-makers on various levels, government leadership and direction become even more important.  
Government leadership and direction should for instance include Clearly appointing a minister responsible for AI, preferably with horizontal responsibilities across ministries
Identify and communicate the potential in the private and public sector
Set a strategy toward realizing such potential 
Establish active international collaboration with leading nations and participation in relevant international initiatives and decision-making (not least in the European Union)
Clearly separate AI from the broadly used term digitalization
The Government should also actively increase competence and use of AI throughout the government office (“Regeringskansliet”). Ideally, each ministry would appoint two to three knowledgeable and responsible for AI-related questions, as well as having access to coordinating and strategic expertise available for government and government offices.



Dedicated investments on AI - Government

AI is likely the strongest driving force behind the mentioned transformation of society and key leaders in Sweden, such as business leaders, policy-makers, and leaders within the government should immediately start discussing AI according to its magnitude and investing to realize the identified potential. 
Dedicated investments are necessary to demonstrate leadership, substantially increase the knowledge level, build strategic resources build an active ecosystem, and scale collaboration across sectors. The investments should be ramped up towards an ambitious level related to the identified potential.
And, the potential is very high. According to DIGG, in the public sector alone and based on available technology by 2019 (i.e. long before generative AI) the estimated potential is SEK 140 billion per year, or more than SEK 10 billion in missed opportunity for every month that passes without action. 
Government investments will be matched by minimum corresponding investments in both the private and public sectors, and lead to ripple effects and clearly higher economic value throughout the ecosystem. One example is this report from Teknikföretagen. 
According to An AI Strategy for Sweden, government investments in AI should include funding programs that lead to a substantial increase in the knowledge level in the ecosystem, develop strategic resources that are shared with many, enable frontrunners to move faster and share generously, scales the building of the AI ecosystem and collaboration across sectors, and incentivizes international collaboration with leading nations and organizations.
We recommend that the overall investments in AI include significant investments through Vinnova, where the collaborative structures, ecosystems, and knowledge already are in place. 
For reference, one of the most natural countries for Sweden to collaborate with is Canada where between 2022 and 2023, $2.57 billion was invested in AI research in the country, as total AI investment reached $8.64 billion. See more here. 
Further on the top 10 Countries Leading in AI Research and technology in 2023, see here.



Increase investments in innovation in general - Government & Ministry of Climate and Enterprise

With the pace of technological development and demonstrated value and implications, we can conclude that we are in the early phase of significantly transformative times. Perhaps the most transformative times in history. In such times, government general investments driving innovation, applied research and change are more important than ever. 
General investments in innovation and applied research advance development in many sectors and as one effect of many, lead to better generation, higher maturity, and availability of data and data management.
Sweden should make sure it is on par with nations investing the most related to its GDP. 
Again we recommend building on existing structures, and within the total investments in innovation in general, include significantly increased investments through Vinnova.



Upskilling and reskilling - Ministry of Education and Research

Broad programs should be put in place to add AI skills to all educational fields and levels, as well as programs incentivizing both private and public sectors to invest in up- and reskilling of the existing workforce. This is especially important for non-STEM education. 
Introducing new courses in existing curriculums in Universities and University Colleges has proven to take a long time and the Ministry of Education and Research should act to both incentivize and force change, as well as establish new ways for the educational system to bring AI to their students.



Upskilling and reskilling - Universities and University Colleges

The transformation of society means that a large share of the existing workforce needs to be up or reskilled. Although there are existing structures and initiatives, we believe that much more must be done. 
According to the Swedish law “Högskolelagen” " universities and University Colleges have the responsibility for lifelong learning, and Universities and University Colleges should collaborate and challenge existing structures to offer educational opportunities in new ways that scales, such as outside of formal curriculums (we believe the students are interested), professional education basis. 
Good small-scale examples with unexpectedly high interest:    
AI for Executives - professional education offered by three universities in collaboration 
AI - Organization, value, and adoption - where hundreds of students learn about AI in an extracurricular activity




Dedicated investments on AI - Regions and Municipalities

Regions and Municipalities have two significant challenges related to AI
Accelerating their use of AI to manage how demographic changes will impact the available workforce
Making sure their regional private sectors adopt AI and maintain competitiveness.
Regions and Municipalities should invest in their competence and use of AI, and make sure they participate in national collaboration. 
Regions and Municipalities should also invest in programs and projects enabling their regional private sectors to adopt AI. AI Sweden is one such structure that enables regions and municipalities to gain from national and collective investments and participate in active ecosystems and collaboration across sectors.



Competence and use of AI - Government agencies and State owned companies

Unlike Regions and Municipalities, many Government agencies and State-owned companies lack "natural" urgency and incentives to reform through AI. Government agencies will be forced to change due to demographic challenges but for many state-owned companies, the government needs to create and communicate pressure for change to happen. Failure or inability to act will lead to erosion of relevance when citizens and taxpayers compare the outcome and services to other private and public organizations.
But regardless of government pressure or incentive, we recommend every government agency and state-owned company to proactively build AI competence, identify concrete use cases with both high potential and short development time, participate in national collaboration, and identify other organizations serving as good examples and inspiration.



Competence & leadership - Political parties

Political parties should ensure that their relevance, decision-making, and ability to contribute to the positive development of society is built on a solid understanding of AI, its potential, and implications. 
  
Specifically, party leaders and other leading party representatives should demonstrate a basic understanding and be able to engage in discussions about use cases, potentials, and risks.










Phase 2 - Scaling the efforts
One trend is very clear, the ones who understand AI the best, also invest the most. And they increase their efforts regularly. With the urgent actions above in place, decision-makers throughout society will rapidly be motivated to increase investments in scaling adoption and managing the benefits and challenges of AI. 
When this realization starts to happen broadly, we believe many more initiatives and changes will start to be relevant. These could include the following:
A broad update of the educational system, both in terms of a broad use of AI-based learning tools, and new curriculums adapted to the way AI transforms society. In other words, not teach AI skills, but more of, for instance, interpersonal skills and collective intelligence  
An Increasing need and urgency to up- and reskill the existing workforce 
Incentivizing collaboration and the use of certain types of solutions throughout regions, municipalities, and government agencies, through conditional government grants and investments.
Strongly improved regulations for international talent and workforce opportunities to choose and work in Sweden based on an international benchmark
Revision of regulations on the use of public data, public procurement, and other obstacles to using AI. 
Mandatory AI knowledge and skills among leaders and decision-makers in both the private and the public sector
Integrate AI-powered decision-making
We also believe investments will be necessary to compensate for the decentralized public sector and to address growing democratic issues related to welfare services not being provided at equal quality and cost by laggards compared to the best frontrunners. 
Further, AI will be a driving force for deepened international collaboration within the EU, the Nordic countries, and NATO. Over time we expect there to be strong applied research bodies within some of these partnerships to accelerate the development, and Sweden will at the mid-term horizon need to focus on deployment rather than domestic research.








Phase 3 - Manage an AI-driven future 
The future society will be different from today’s. AI will come with many implications that we struggle to foresee today and that will likely need to be managed with a completely different set of tools (such as regulation, taxation, and governance) than today. 
Nations that prepare early and intentionally establish cultures, foresight, and structures that enable adaptivity should have good chances to be the best at managing the economic, social, and other challenges the AI transformation might bring.



















PART 5
Responsible use of AI








AI has the potential to transform whole industries as well as society at large. It is of the highest importance that this is done in a safe, lawful, and responsible way to make sure people are not harmed directly or indirectly through applied AI solutions, while also unlocking the potential that AI brings.
The pace of AI development is extremely high. This brings a strong need for paying close attention to the implications of adopting AI while also building trust on a societal level and over time. Each AI use case has unique risks and considerations that require context-specific approaches. We also need to support experimentation and exploration as this is where potential risks are concretized and addressed. 
Moreover, due to the speed of development, we are not yet able to foresee all possible risks and opportunities with AI. It is therefore paramount that we build a strong AI ecosystem that is capable of applying responsible principles over time. A robust AI ecosystem requires national and international collaboration, active contribution and participation of stakeholders, and sharing of information and best practices.
The adoption of AI spans many fields, both technical such as data management and infrastructure, and non-technical areas such as behavioral sciences and people management. Given this, a multi-disciplinary approach throughout the lifecycle of AI development and application will increase our understanding of how AI solutions will be the most useful without producing undesirable results and the effect on society as a whole. 
For organizations developing or using AI, we encourage using existing work done by organizations such as EU, NATO, OECD, and UNESCO, and we would like to place additional emphasis on some specific perspectives.













Lawfulness and transparency: All AI solutions should be developed and used within the rule of the law and stakeholders should be held accountable accordingly. We strongly advocate for proportionate and reasonable transparency about how AI systems are developed and work. This involves communicating the capabilities and limitations of AI understandably to all stakeholders, including end users and citizens.
















Ethical and fair: AI systems must be designed and operated in a manner that respects human rights, values, and cultural diversity. This includes mitigating risks with AI algorithms such as bias and discrimination. It is essential to consider ethical implications at every stage of AI development and deployment.















Safety and robustness: AI systems must be reliable, controllable, and secure. They should function as intended under various conditions and be resilient to manipulations and errors. This includes safeguarding against malicious use of AI technologies and ensuring that AI does not pose unintended harm to people or the environment.












Assuming an agreement on the above principles, the challenge now lies in turning them into action and translating them into real-life scenarios and applications. Here, we have a responsibility to also use AI where appropriate and to address our time’s most pressing global challenges.











References

EU ethics guidelines for trustworthy AI
UNESCO: recommendation on the ethics of artificial intelligence
OECD: OECD AI Principles overview
EU AI Act Proposal
NATO AI Strategy

Result Page - Data Readiness Lab






Bridging the Data Gap in Organizations
The Data Readiness Lab is more than a project; it's a commitment to empowering organizations to harness the full potential of their data. Whether you are starting your AI journey or you are a professional, our lab's deliverables are designed to guide you through the multifaceted realm of data-intensive processes.
















(In Swedish)






The Data Readiness Lab has been initiated with a core vision: to equip organizations and companies with the necessary skills, tools, framework, and resources to enhance their data readiness. Recognizing the pivotal role of data in realizing projects, our lab's outcomes are relevant for both the public and private sectors. 








Result Overview
1. Case Studies from the Public Sector (In Swedish)
A compilation of four case studies that shed light on the intricacies of acquiring and utilizing data, emphasizing aspects like data availability, validity, and utility. These studies draw experiences from:
Strängnäs Kommun
Sveriges Kommuner och Regioner (SKR)
Arbetsförmedlingen
Ekonomistyrningsverket (ESV).
Insights from diverse organizations at varying stages of data maturity provide valuable takeaways. Through the provided examples, we want to offer insights and encourage thoughtfulness, and discussions on best practices, contribute to better decision-making in AI applications, and raise awareness of these issues as they are often overlooked.
For a holistic understanding, we recommend beginning with these case studies. Additionally, to assess the readiness of your chosen dataset, consider the data maturity analysis method that we used in our lab:
Roots of the Data Readiness Assessment Method:
	Our approach to determining data maturity traces back to a joint venture with Gavagai and AI Sweden (see the paper “We Need to Talk About Data: The Importance of Data Readiness in Natural Language Processing”). The method evaluates data from the perspectives of availability, validity, and usability. This method has been tested during the project and also made accessible in an Excel format.
 
2: Text Annotation Handbook (In English)
A practical guide for machine learning projects. This handbook is a hands-on guide on how to approach text annotation tasks. It provides a gentle introduction to the topic, an overview of theoretical concepts as well as practical advice. The topics covered are mostly technical, but business, ethical and regulatory issues are also touched upon. Experience with annotation and knowledge of machine learning are useful but not required. The document may serve as a primer or reference book for a wide range of professionals such as team leaders, project managers, IT architects, software developers and machine learning engineers.
 
3. Tools for Practitioners:

Anonymization Tool: nerblackbox, an open-source tool that can be locally installed and that focuses on Anonymization and pseudonymization through Named Entity Recognition (NER). It uses name recognition to identify, delete, or replace personal details. Link to GitHubFind more details in this documentation.


Tool for cross-annotation:x-annotate, a project management tool for cross-annotation with popular annotation frameworks. It provides a simple command line interface (CLI) that lets you split data between annotators, merge annotations and resolve conflicts. Link to GitHub

 
4. Training Material on Data Readiness
This material is available on our platform MyAI. Sign up for free to access it. 
The training aims to provide an overview and the opportunity to get started with your project by taking a closer look at the lessons learned and methods used in the Data Readiness Lab.
The material is divided into three parts where you can easily choose what suits you, in whichever order you prefer.

Resultatsida - Data Readiness Lab






Överbrygga datagapet i organisationer
Data Readiness Lab är mer än ett projekt; det är ett åtagande att ge organisationer möjlighet att utnyttja sin datas fulla potential. Oavsett om du börjar din AI-resa eller om du är en professionell, är våra leveranser utformade för att guida dig genom den mångfacetterade sfären av dataintensiva processer.




















Data Readiness Lab initierades med en kärnvision: att rusta organisationer och företag med nödvändiga kunskaper, verktyg, ramverk och resurser för att förbättra deras databeredskap. Vårt labbs resultat är relevanta för både den offentliga och privata sektorn, eftersom vi inser den avgörande roll som data spelar för att förverkliga projekt.








Resultatöversikt
1. Fallstudier från offentlig sektor (på svenska)
En sammanställning av fyra fallstudier som belyser svårigheterna med att skaffa och använda data, med betoning på aspekter som datatillgänglighet, validitet och användbarhet. Dessa studier hämtar erfarenheter från:
Strängnäs Kommun
Sveriges Kommuner och Regioner (SKR)
Arbetsförmedlingen
Ekonomistyrningsverket (ESV)
Insikter från olika organisationer i olika stadier av datamognad ger värdefulla takeaways. Genom de medföljande exemplen vill vi erbjuda lärdomar och uppmuntra till eftertänksamhet och diskussioner om bästa praxis, bidra till bättre beslutsfattande i AI-tillämpningar och öka medvetenheten om dessa frågor eftersom de ofta förbises.
För en helhetsförståelse rekommenderar vi att du börjar med dessa fallstudier. Dessutom, för att bedöma beredskapen hos din valda datamängd, överväga analysmetoden för datamognad som vi använde i vårt labb:
Roots of the Data Readiness Assessment Method
	Vårt tillvägagångssätt för att bestämma datamognad går tillbaka till ett samarbete mellan Gavagai och AI Sweden (se artikeln "Vi behöver prata om data: betydelsen av databeredskap i naturlig språkbehandling”). Metoden utvärderar data utifrån perspektiven tillgänglighet, validitet och användbarhet. Denna metod har testats under projektet och även gjorts tillgänglig i Excel-format. 
 
2: Text Annotation Handbook (på engelska)
En praktisk guide för maskininlärningsprojekt. Den här handboken är en praktisk guide om hur man närmar sig annotering av data. Den ger en introduktion till ämnet, en översikt över teoretiska begrepp samt praktiska råd. Ämnena som behandlas är mestadels tekniska, men affärsmässiga, etiska och regulatoriska frågor berörs också. Erfarenhet av annotering och kunskap om maskininlärning är användbara men inget krav. Dokumentet kan fungera som en primer eller referensbok för ett brett spektrum av yrken som teamledare, projektledare, IT-arkitekter, mjukvaruutvecklare och maskininlärningsingenjörer.
 
3.Verktyg för utövare:

Anonymiseringsverktyg:nerblackbox, ett verktyg med öppen källkod som kan installeras lokalt och som fokuserar på anonymisering och pseudonymisering genom Named Entity Recognition (NER). Den använder namnigenkänning för att identifiera, ta bort eller ersätta personliga uppgifter. Länk till GitHubLäs mer i tillhörande artikel här.


Verktyg för x-annotate:x-annotate, ett projekthanteringsverktyg för korsannotering med populära annoteringsramverk. Den tillhandahåller ett enkelt kommandoradsgränssnitt (CLI) som låter dig dela data mellan annotatorer, slå samman anteckningar och lösa konflikter. Länk till GitHub

 
4.Träningsmaterial om databeredskap
Detta material finns tillgängligt på vår plattform MyAI. Registrera dig gratis för att komma åt det.
Utbildningen syftar till att ge en överblick och möjlighet att komma igång med ditt projekt genom att titta närmare på lärdomar och metoder som används i Data Readiness Workshop.
Materialet är uppdelat i tre delar där du enkelt kan välja vad som passar dig, i vilken ordning du än föredrar.

Master Thesis Program






In the spring of 2023, the Master Thesis Program welcomed students from Chalmers University of Technology, the Swedish University of Agricultural Sciences, Gothenburg School of Economics, and partners including Centiro, RISE, Zenseact, SLU, Recorded Future, Volvo Cars, and AstraZeneca. We are now ready for a new round starting in January 2024 and are looking to start the program in Gothenburg, Linköping, Luleå, Lund and Örebro.









 










Drawing upon the valuable insights shared by students and the wealth of experience gained from previous program cycles, we aim to provide support to the new cohort of students in some of the tasks that are well-known for being commonly overlooked. We invite the students to a series of workshops (once a month from February to April) to help them develop their soft skills, such as giving a talk and writing a master thesis. They will be welcomed into our offices for the period of their thesis work and we will offer a quiet space, access to our infrastructure and technical support, not to mention a friendly environment.
Is your organization interested in gaining value and new perspectives from masters students at some of the top universities in Sweden?













How to take part (as a supervisor)
Please register your interest by sending an email with a description of your suggested topic for one or more master theses to sofia.heden@ai.se and chiara.ceccobello@ai.se and post it on My.AI under Resources/Master Thesis Proposals by October 31.
The description should include:
Name of the project
Short description of the topic
Your organization
Your contact person and email address
Preferred student background
​Preferred location
The thesis work will begin in January 2024. We will help you spread the word and recruit the best students for your project.












What can partners expect?
Student-industry collaborations are mutually beneficial. They create opportunities to share new insights and points of view while building competence and expertise on both sides.
Benefit from the knowledge of master students to solve current problems or dig deeper into existing tasks. Boost attractiveness to possible future employees by joining these collaborations. Opportunity to recruit students directly before they graduate.













How to take part (as a student)
If you already have an AI-related thesis, express your interest in the program by sending your application. 






Send in your application






We rarely provide master thesis projects from AI Sweden, but encourage you to go to My AI to find suggestions from partners and other organizations in the AI ecosystem. You will find suggestions under Resources - Master Thesis (Resurser - Exjobbsförslag). The page will be updated with new proposals regularly.
If you are looking for a thesis topic/project, go to My.AI under Resources/Master Thesis and contact the reference person of the master thesis project that interests you and hopefully, we will see you around in January. Once you find a project, send your application to participate in the program here.












What can candidates expect?
Valuable experience from working with real projects and applying theoretical knowledge.
A community where you can benefit from each other’s experiences and challenges in different organizations and sectors.
Attend exclusive events, lectures, and other activities.
Working with the best in the field across Sweden.
About the program
Students who enter the program work on the topics that matter most to partners and sit at one of our locations. They benefit from events and seminars from AI Sweden experts during the spring focused on growing their soft skills and providing extra support on common struggles, such as the writing process and defining and sticking to the research question that they want to address in their thesis work. Last but not least, they will have access to the Data Factory, the Edge Learning Lab and DGX A100, and other resources. 
See examples of previous students' topics on My AI
In spring 2022 the cohort welcomed students from Chalmers and SLU, and partners including Zenseact, SLU, Unibap, Volvo, and AstraZeneca. Some of the dissertations picked up on challenges and created greater awareness within topics such as cyber security, both at partners and AI Sweden.

"This is a great example of a low risk, low effort initiative, where organizations can explore and develop new areas." - Kim Henriksson, Project Manager at AI Sweden’s Edge Lab

Head of Talent Programs

Master Thesis Program






Våren 2023 välkomnade Master Thesis Program studenter från Chalmers tekniska högskola, Sveriges lantbruksuniversitet, Handelshögskolan i Göteborg, samt partners som Centiro, RISE, Zenseact, SLU, Recorded Future, Volvo Cars och AstraZeneca. Vi är nu redo för en ny omgång som startar i januari 2024 och ser fram emot att starta programmet i Göteborg, Linköping, Luleå, Lund och Örebro.









 










Genom att dra nytta av värdefulla insikter som delas av studenter och rik erfarenhet från tidigare programcykler, syftar vi till att ge stöd till den nya studentkullen i vissa av de uppgifter som är kända för att ofta bli förbisedda. Vi bjuder in studenterna till en serie workshops (en gång i månaden från februari till april) för att hjälpa dem att utveckla sina mjuka färdigheter, såsom att hålla ett anförande och skriva en magisteruppsats. De kommer att välkomnas in i våra kontor under perioden för deras examensarbete och vi kommer att erbjuda ett lugnt utrymme, tillgång till vår infrastruktur och tekniskt stöd, för att inte tala om en vänlig miljö.
Är din organisation intresserad av att få värde och nya perspektiv från magisterstudenter vid några av de bästa universiteten i Sverige?













Hur man deltar (som handledare)
Var god registrera ditt intresse genom att skicka ett e-postmeddelande med en beskrivning av ditt föreslagna ämne för en eller flera magisteruppsatser till sofia.heden@ai.se och chiara.ceccobello@ai.se och posta det på My.AI under Resources/Master Thesis Proposals före den 31 oktober.
Beskrivningen ska inkludera:
Projektets namn
Kort beskrivning av ämnet
Din organisation
Din kontaktperson och e-postadress
Föredragen studentbakgrund
​Föredragen plats
Examensarbetet kommer att börja i januari 2024. Vi kommer att hjälpa dig att sprida ordet och rekrytera de bästa studenterna till ditt projekt.












Vad kan partners förvänta sig?
Student-industri-samarbeten är ömsesidigt fördelaktiga. De skapar möjligheter att dela nya insikter och synpunkter samtidigt som de bygger kompetens och expertis på båda sidor.
Dra nytta av kunskapen från magisterstudenter för att lösa aktuella problem eller gräva djupare i befintliga uppgifter. Öka attraktiviteten för framtida anställda genom att delta i dessa samarbeten. Möjlighet att rekrytera studenter direkt innan de tar examen.













Hur man deltar (som student)
Om du redan har ett AI-relaterat examensarbete, uttryck ditt intresse i programmet genom att skicka in din ansökan.






Skicka in din ansökan






Vi erbjuder sällan examensarbeten från AI Sweden, men vi uppmanar dig att gå till My AI för att hitta förslag från partners och andra organisationer i AI-ekosystemet. Du hittar förslag under Resources - Master Thesis (Resurser - Exjobbsförslag). Sidan kommer att uppdateras med nya förslag regelbundet.
Om du letar efter ett ämne/projekt för ditt examensarbete, gå till My.AI under Resources/Master Thesis och kontakta referenspersonen för det masterprojekt som intresserar dig och förhoppningsvis kommer vi att se dig runt i januari. När du hittar ett projekt, skicka in din ansökan för att delta i programmet här.












Vad kan kandidater förvänta sig?
Värdefull erfarenhet av att arbeta med verkliga projekt och tillämpa teoretiska kunskaper.
Ett community där du kan dra nytta av varandras erfarenheter och utmaningar i olika organisationer och sektorer.
Delta i exklusiva evenemang, föreläsningar och andra aktiviteter.
Arbeta med de bästa inom fältet över hela Sverige.
Om programmet
Studenter som går med i programmet arbetar med de ämnen som är viktigast för partners och sitter på en av våra platser. De drar nytta av evenemang och seminarier från AI Sverige-experter under våren med fokus på att utveckla sina mjuka färdigheter och ger extra stöd för vanliga problem, såsom skrivprocessen och att definiera och hålla sig till forskningsfrågan som de vill adressera i sitt examensarbete. Sist men inte minst kommer de ha tillgång till Data Factory, Edge Learning Lab och DGX A100, och andra resurser. 
Se exempel på tidigare studentämnen på My AI
Våren 2022 välkomnade kullen studenter från Chalmers och SLU, samt partners som Zenseact, SLU, Unibap, Volvo och AstraZeneca. Några av avhandlingarna tog upp utmaningar och skapade större medvetenhet inom ämnen som cybersäkerhet, både hos partners och AI Sverige.

"Det här är ett bra exempel på en lågrisk, lågansträngningsinitiativ, där organisationer kan utforska och utveckla nya områden." - Kim Henriksson, Project Manager at AI Sweden’s Edge Lab

AI Vision






AI Sweden and partners Centiro, Region Gävleborg, Sahlgrenska University Hospital, the Swedish Tax Agency, Västra Götalandsregionen, Zenseact and Östgötatrafiken have developed a AI Vision White Paper. Download a guiding white paper and a template to help your organization set their AI vision faster and with better results.









 








Download the AI Vision White Paper






An AI vision sets the direction for working with AI. Organizations that are increasing their focus on AI can benefit from getting aligned behind a vision that creates a better understanding of AI and its place in the organization. Without a vision, organizations risk putting too little focus on the most valuable projects, or worse; spending resources on the wrong ones. In a recent report, McKinsey found that companies that see the highest return on investment from AI are much more likely to have a clearly defined AI vision and strategy.  However, developing an AI vision can be complicated and achieving the intended impact can be hard. Not much guidance has so far been produced on what goes into an AI vision and there have been few best practice references. 
The white paper is a guide developed to help organizations create their AI vision faster and with better results. This practical tool is the product of AI Swedens and the collaborating partners' combined experiences. It explains what an AI vision is, the process of creating it and how to communicate it. In addition to the white paper, an easy-to-use template accompanies it.  
Who can benefit from using the white paper?
Private or public, any organization that wants to work more with AI could benefit from it. Ideally, an AI vision is developed after the organization has developed its first experiments or proof of concepts. The AI vision serves as a roadmap for further scaling. 
Why did we create the AI Vision White Paper?
“We wanted to create this white paper because it is something all of us would have loved to have access to when we first started working on setting an AI strategy. By getting this paper out, the hope is to help other organizations speed up their process and bring clarity,” says Lucas Ambjörn, Expert in Digitization and AI Transformation at Zenseact, one of the contributors to the whitepaper. 
Another contributor, Cecilia Hahn Berg, Strategist for Life Science at Sahlgrenska University Hospital also shares her view on how the paper could benefit organizations:
 “Spending 30 minutes reading through the white paper will hopefully pay back in at least two ways. Firstly, to speed up the process of deciding if an AI vision will benefit your organization at all. Second, the white paper will help you understand how to set up the process to create an AI vision.” 
Collaborating across sectors 
The AI Vision White Paper was developed by a broad combination of organizations, ranging from public to private and from large to medium-sized. The work was done in a series of workshops spanning over three months. “We could build in all our knowledge in the paper from different companies and authorities,” says Anders Fryden, AI coordinator and Change Manager at the Swedish Tax Agency. Cecilia Hahn Berg added that “the wide-ranging perspectives hopefully result in a white paper that is applicable to a broader audience.” 
During the workshops, the group gathered knowledge and inspiration from other sources as well as sharing their own experiences. 
The AI Vision White Paper is available in both English and Swedish.

AI-vision






AI Sweden och våra partners Centiro, Region Gävleborg, Sahlgrenska Universitetssjukhuset, Skatteverket, Västra Götalandsregionen, Zenseact och Östgötatrafiken har utvecklat en vitbok om AI-vision. Ladda ner en vägledande vitbok och en mall för att hjälpa din organisation att sätta sin AI-vision snabbare och med bättre resultat.









 








Ladda ner AI Vision White Paper






En AI-vision sätter riktningen för att arbeta med AI. Organisationer som ökar sitt fokus på AI kan dra nytta av att bli samordnade bakom en vision som skapar en bättre förståelse för AI och dess plats i organisationen. Utan en vision riskerar organisationer att lägga för lite fokus på de mest värdefulla projekten, eller ännu värre; att spendera resurser på de fel projekten. I en ny rapport, fann McKinsey att företag som ser den högsta avkastningen på investeringar från AI är mycket mer benägna att ha en tydligt definierad AI-vision och strategi. Att utveckla en AI-vision kan dock vara komplicerat och det kan vara svårt att uppnå den avsedda påverkan. Hittills har inte mycket vägledning producerats om vad som ingår i en AI-vision och det har funnits få bästa praxis referenser.
Vitboken är en guide utvecklad för att hjälpa organisationer att skapa sin AI-vision snabbare och med bättre resultat. Detta praktiska verktyg är produkten av AI Swedens och de samarbetande partnernas samlade erfarenheter. Den förklarar vad en AI-vision är, processen att skapa den och hur man kommunicerar den. Förutom vitboken medföljer en lättanvänd mall. 
Vilka kan dra nytta av att detta material?
Privata eller offentliga, alla organisationer som vill arbeta mer med AI kan dra nytta av den. Idealiskt utvecklas en AI-vision efter att organisationen har utvecklat sina första experiment eller proof of concepts. AI-visionen fungerar som en färdplan för vidare skalning.
Varför tog vi fram AI Vision White Paper?
"Vi ville skapa denna vitbok eftersom det är något som alla av oss skulle ha älskat att ha tillgång till när vi först började arbeta med att sätta en AI-strategi. Genom att få ut detta dokument hoppas vi hjälpa andra organisationer att accelerera sin process och skapa klarhet," säger Lucas Ambjörn, Expert på Digitalisering och AI Transformation på Zenseact, en av bidragsgivarna till vitboken.
En annan bidragsgivare, Cecilia Hahn Berg, Strateg för Life Science på Sahlgrenska Universitetssjukhuset, delar också sin syn på hur pappret kan gynna organisationer:
"Att tillbringa 30 minuter med att läsa igenom vitboken kommer förhoppningsvis att betala sig på minst två sätt. För det första, för att accelerera processen att bestämma om en AI-vision kommer att gynna din organisation överhuvudtaget. För det andra kommer vitboken att hjälpa dig att förstå hur du ställer in processen för att skapa en AI-vision."
Samarbeta över sektorer
Vitboken om AI-vision utvecklades av en bred kombination av organisationer, från offentliga till privata och från stora till medelstora. Arbetet utfördes i en serie workshops som sträckte sig över tre månader. "Vi kunde bygga in all vår kunskap i dokumentet från olika företag och myndigheter", säger Anders Fryden, AI samordnare och Change Manager på Skatteverket. Cecilia Hahn Berg tillade att "de varierande perspektiven förhoppningsvis resulterar i en vitbok som gäller för en bredare publik."
Under workshops samlade gruppen kunskap och inspiration från andra källor samt delade sina egna erfarenheter.
Vitboken om AI Vision finns tillgänglig både på engelska och svenska.

AI on a strategic level






AI will change the world that your organization operates in, whether you are in the private or public sector. But for AI to also be a tool for your organization to create value and solve challenges there are active decisions that you have to make. As a decision-maker, you have to understand artificial intelligence. Not the technical details, but what AI can do.









 










It does not matter if you work in the public or private sector, or in our government leading Sweden on a national level. Artificial intelligence opens up new opportunities. Adopting AI requires making strategic decisions. Make sure that the right stakeholders are involved. Prioritize between use cases. Build partnerships with the best out there. Allocate substantial and appropriate resources. Create an environment for organizational learning.
AI Sweden has a lot of resources to aid in this process, depending on where you and your organization are today.
Stay up to date on the latest news by subscribing to our newsletter for decision makers





What do I need to know about AI?

As a decision maker you do not have to strive for deep technical knowledge about artificial intelligence. But you need to understand what AI can do so that you can have an understanding of how the technology affects your organization – both as a force that transforms the reality your organization exists in but more importantly how AI can be used as a tool within your organization.
Make sure to check out the executive program “AI for executives” which is intended for non-technical decision makers who want to develop their understanding of how to strategically implement AI in their organization. The program is developed by the executive education units at Stockholm University, Uppsala University, and Gothenburg University, in collaboration with AI Sweden.
You can also listen to our podcast AI för ledare och CxO:er and take the self-paced, free course “Get started with AI”, and then continue with “Level up”. 
For inspiration on what others do with the help of AI, do not miss out on exploring the use case library at My AI.



How do we start using AI?

For organizations to truly adopt AI, it is necessary to change ways of working, processes, and structures. This makes it a question for decision-makers and top levels of every organization. To embark on this transformative journey, organizations can use a step-by-step approach that focuses on key enablers —Technology, Data & Infrastructure, Organization, Ecosystem, and Expertise. By doing so, organizations can generate sustainable value using AI. Read more about how to adopt AI and accelerate your organization's AI maturity here.



How do I make strategic decisions about AI in my organizations?

To scale and move forward you need to understand where your organization stands today. Doing an AI maturity assessment is one way to understand the current state of your organization’s AI maturity and gives you a clear idea of where to go next. 
Having an AI vision is another way to approach AI strategically. The AI Vision White Paper is a tool that helps organizations put an AI vision in place.



How do I develop the right AI competence in my organization?

For partners to AI Sweden, there are talent programs you can join. Some run over a few weeks, others are 1,5 years. This way, we address various partner needs and at the same time boost talent with relevant knowledge.
But recruiting is not the only way of course. There are also resources for upskilling that you can check out.



How do others use AI in my sector?

Explore the use case library at MyAI. But do not only look at what others in your sector do with AI. Since artificial intelligence is a general technology, we find that many organizations can learn from each other as they share the same challenges - do not hesitate to find inspiration outside of your sector as well.
AI Sweden also has sector-specific networks that might be of interest to you. Once you are a partner, get in touch with your key contact to get more information.



How do we become partners to AI Sweden?

First, read more about the partnership. Second, find your sector contact and get in touch for further discussions.



How can AI be used in politics?

Just as for any other organization - AI will be key for a well-functioning government. Read more about the organizational perspective here. 
But perhaps even more important, AI is a key component for fulfilling almost every societal goal in a country. As a political decision maker, you will be making priorities for an entire sector or an entire country. Understanding the strategic dimension of AI, financial and political priorities, and developing sound policy will be a pillar for any politician who wants to be relevant in our world today. Get in touch with Mikael Ljungblom, Director of Public Policy and International Relations at AI Sweden if you have questions.

AI på en strategisk nivå






AI kommer att förändra världen som din organisation verkar i, oavsett om du är i den privata eller offentliga sektorn. Men för att AI också ska vara ett verktyg för din organisation att skapa värde och lösa utmaningar finns det aktiva beslut som du måste fatta. Som beslutsfattare behöver du förstå artificiell intelligens. Inte de tekniska detaljerna, men vad AI kan göra.









 










Det spelar ingen roll om du arbetar inom den offentliga eller privata sektorn, eller i vår regering som leder Sverige på nationell nivå. Artificiell intelligens öppnar upp nya möjligheter. Att införa AI kräver att man fattar strategiska beslut. Se till att de rätta intressenterna är involverade. Prioritera mellan användningsfall. Bygg partnerskap med de bästa där ute. Allokera signifikanta och relevanta resurser. Skapa en miljö för organisatoriskt lärande. AI Sweden har mycket resurser för att hjälpa till i denna process, beroende på var du och din organisation befinner er idag.
 
Håll dig uppdaterad med de senaste nyheterna genom att prenumerera på vårt nyhetsbrev för beslutsfattare





Vad behöver jag veta om AI?

Som beslutsfattare behöver du inte sträva efter djup teknisk kunskap om artificiell intelligens. Men du behöver förstå vad AI kan göra så att du kan förstå hur tekniken påverkar din organisation - både som en kraft som omvandlar verkligheten som din organisation existerar i och, mer viktigt, hur AI kan användas som ett verktyg inom din organisation.
Programmet AI for executives är avsett för icke-tekniska beslutsfattare som vill utveckla sin förståelse för hur man strategiskt implementerar AI i sin organisation. Programmet är utvecklat av enheterna för chefsutbildning vid Stockholms universitet, Uppsala universitet och Göteborgs universitet, i samarbete med AI Sweden.
Du kan också lyssna på vår podcast AI för ledare och CxO:er och gå den kostnadsfria kursen Starta din AI-resa i den takt som passar dig, och sedan fortsätta med Level up.
För inspiration om vad andra gör med hjälp av AI, missa inte att utforska use case-biblioteket på My AI.



Hur börjar vi använda AI?

För att organisationer verkligen ska kunna växla ut värdet av AI är det nödvändigt att inte bara se det som en teknisk resurs utan också ändra arbetssätt, processer och strukturer. Detta gör det till en fråga för beslutsfattare på högsta nivån inom varje organisation. Ett sätt för organisationer att ta sig an AI-resan är genom ett steg-för-steg tillvägagångssätt som fokuserar på nyckelfaktorer - Teknologi, Data & Infrastruktur, Organisation, Ekosystem och Expertis. Genom detta kan organisationer generera hållbart värde med hjälp av AI. Läs mer om hur du kan införa AI och accelerera din organisations AI-mognad här.



Hur fattar jag strategiska beslut om AI i mina organisationer?

Ett första steg är att göra en AI Maturity Assessment. Det ger både insikt i var din organisation står idag och ger en förståelse för att sätta rätt riktning framåt.
Att ha en AI-vision är ett annat sätt att strategiskt närma sig AI. AI Vision White Paper är ett verktyg som hjälper organisationer att införa en AI-vision.



Hur utvecklar jag rätt AI-kompetens i min organisation?

Partners till AI Sweden kan engagera sig i våra talangprogram för att attrahera ny kompetens. Vissa pågår under några veckor, andra är 1,5 år. På så sätt bemöter vi olika partners behov och samtidigt boostar talang med relevant kunskap. Mer om AI Swedens partnerskap.
Men rekrytering är inte det enda sättet. Det finns också resurser för vidareutbildning som du kan kolla in.



Hur använder andra AI i min sektor?

Utforska use case-biblioteket på My AI. AI Sweden har också branschspecifika nätverk som kan vara av intresse för dig. Men titta inte bara på vad andra inom din sektor gör med AI. Eftersom artificiell intelligens är en generell teknik kan många organisationer lära av varandra eftersom de delar samma utmaningar - tveka inte att hitta inspiration utanför din sektor också.



Hur blir vi partners till AI Sweden?

Läs mer om partnerskapet och ansök om att bli partner här.



Hur kan AI användas i politiken?

Likaväl som för vilken annan organisation som helst kommer AI att vara nyckeln till en väl fungerande regering. Läs mer om den organisatoriska synvinkeln. Men kanske ännu viktigare är att AI är en nyckelkomponent för att uppfylla nästan varje samhällsmål i ett land.
Som politisk beslutsfattare kommer du att göra prioriteringar för en hel sektor eller ett helt land. Att förstå den strategiska dimensionen av AI, ekonomiska och politiska prioriteringar, samt att utveckla en sund politik kommer att vara en grundpelare för varje politiker som vill vara relevant i vår värld idag. Kontakta Mikael Ljungblom, Director of Public Policy and International Relations på AI Sweden om du har några frågor.
